abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Mahakali
            Irrigation Project for Nepal was satisfactory. The project
            achieved its main objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been substantial, sustainability is likely,
            and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, participation of beneficiaries in the
            design, construction, implementation, and O&M from the
            outset is very important, especially in large public
            irrigation systems. Second, service charges to cover full
            O&M costs of public utilities after improvement must be
            imposed and considered as a national policy in any
            investment project. Third, economic analysis before
            implementation of FMIS sub-projects was often inadequate.
            HMGN must take steps to ensure rigorous appraisal of future
            schemes' viability. Fourth, it is not reasonable to
            expect increased agricultural extension input from the DADO
            if additional resources are not allocated to DADO for this
            purpose. Finally, the WUA's responsibility for the
            O&M of new schemes must be carefully and clearly defined
            at the outset.
